summary: Random hopes and head canons for Arya and Sansa
title: Random hopes and head canons for Arya and Sansa
body:
- Sansa dressing Arya. Making a Arya a Catelyn-like collar or an embroidered cloak with a wolf. Arya needs to dress more like a Stark, damnit! It would be doubly interesting if Sansa finds some of Lyanna’s things and gives them to Arya.

- Sansa teaching Arya about the politics of the North, showing Arya the boring parts of ruling it. I’m not sure if Arya still has this romanticized notion of what being a Lord is, someone who fights in wars and has adventures, but it mostly involves management of your castle and lands. This would allow some of Arya’s protective instincts to shine through, maybe even recalling what Robb quoted from Ned about how everyone in the North is theirs to protect. Sansa is proud and happy to Arya’s support.

- Arya teaching Sansa some basic fighting skills. Jon did say that all of the boys and girls would need to learn how to fight. Sansa would not remove herself from that obligation. Maybe she tricks Arya a little? Arya hits Sansa during their lesson and Sansa pretends to be hurt worse than she is. Arya starts to apologize and Sansa pushes her down. Sansa makes a point to Arya about Cersei and how tricky and manipulative she is. How they can’t fight Cersei the same way they will fight the Night King and Cersei might be just as dangerous as he is.

My highest hope for next season is for Arya and Sansa to be there for each other. Listening to each other. Understanding each other. I don’t think we’ll get any hackneyed fight like last season but I hope they don’t let their relationship completely fall by the way side for more “important” things.

summary: One man showed her how to tie sailor's knots. Another poured her thimble cups of fire wine. The friendly ones would tap their...
body:
One man showed her how to tie sailor’s knots. Another poured her thimble cups of fire wine. The friendly ones would tap their chests, repeating their names over and over until Arya said them back, though none ever thought to ask her name.

He taught her how to hide it up her sleeve and slip it out when she had need of it, and how to slice a purse so smooth and quick the coins would all be spent before their owner ever missed them.

They bought clams and cockles from her, told her true tales of Braavos and lies about their lives, and laughed at the way she talked when she tried to speak Braavosi.

Gyloro Dothare taught her filthy songs, and his brother Gyleno told her the best places to catch eels. The mummers off the Ship showed her how a hero stands, and taught her speeches from The Song of the Rhoyne, The Conqueror’s Two Wives, and The Merchant’s Lusty Lady. 

the amount of stuff arya’s learning in braavos is amazing. im not talking about her faceless training either; just being in the city is such an informative experience. i love how it feels like a real port with a super diverse community of people. 

it seems like mundane stuff; tying knots, picking pockets, speeches, songs, but every bit of information expands arya’s view of the world and - most importantly - those who live in it. she’s being exposed to so many cultures, languages, and religions. thats how you learn people. it shows her willingness and interest in listening to people from all walks of life too. just like she was in winterfell. arya’s nature has always been open and understanding and compassionate. she’s not living the sheltered existence of most highborn who barely know what happens in their own castles. arya is becoming worldly wise.

blog.name: andthemaidenfair
blog.title: By The Old Gods and The New

tags: A Song of Ice and Fire
summary: Honestly I read Sansa and Arya’s relationship as more of an average sibling rivalry than anything else. I’ve seen a lot of...
body:
Honestly I read Sansa and Arya’s relationship as more of an average sibling rivalry than anything else. I’ve seen a lot of people claim that the sisters hated each other and made each other miserable but I just don’t see that in the books.

TLDR: Sometimes a sibling rivalry is just a sibling rivalry.

My brother and I were close in age and bickered and fought constantly as kids. We’d get all worked up and say mean things or “tattle” or shove each other and it would be a whole thing. My brother and I weren’t pitted against each other by our family, friends, or teachers. But we still argued regularly. We still developed a competitive relationship that lasted throughout our childhoods. 

But we grew out of it. Around the time I was 16 my brother quite suddenly became my friend, ally, and confidant. We had developed the maturity needed to use our words and take a minute to consider that the other might not be trying to upset us, or to just walk away sometimes. We also began to understand that  the nasty things we said and did to each other did matter. It wasn’t until I was 17 that I realized that what I’d thought was joke teasing had actually hurt him. I didn’t even think I had the ability to hurt his feelings. And he had the same realization about me. Regardless of our petty fights we never hated each other. In fact when we weren’t squabbling together we were playing together. 

 I’ve never had a sister and I don’t live in the asoiaf misogynistic society that so openly and structurally calculates ones worth on gender based accomplishments so it’s not quite the same situation. But I do see a lot of my own sibling relationship in Arya and Sansa. One based on mutual immaturity rather than mutual hatred. 

I do think that it would have been more difficult than just suddenly growing out of their antagonistic relationship if The Plot not happened. The world they live in supports Sansa’s view of Arya as an embarrassing wild child and one of them might have still been sent away as a ward or bride before they could work things out. I don’t think they would ever truly see eye to eye but I do think that they could have grown and matured enough to love and support one another. Or to at least be on friendly terms.
body_abstract:
Honestly I read Sansa and Arya’s relationship as more of an average sibling rivalry than anything else. I’ve seen a lot of people claim that the sisters hated each other and made each other miserable but I just don’t see that in the books.

TLDR: Sometimes a sibling rivalry is just a sibling rivalry.

TLDR: Sometimes a sibling rivalry is just a sibling rivalry.

My brother and I were close in age and bickered and fought constantly as kids. We’d get all worked up and say mean things or “tattle” or shove each other and it would be a whole thing. My brother and I weren’t pitted against each other by our family, friends, or teachers. But we still argued regularly. We still developed a competitive relationship that lasted throughout our childhoods. 

But we grew out of it. Around the time I was 16 my brother quite suddenly became my friend, ally, and confidant. We had developed the maturity needed to use our words and take a minute to consider that the other might not be trying to upset us, or to just walk away sometimes. We also began to understand that  the nasty things we said and did to each other did matter. It wasn’t until I was 17 that I realized that what I’d thought was joke teasing had actually hurt him. I didn’t even think I had the ability to hurt his feelings. And he had the same realization about me. Regardless of our petty fights we never hated each other. In fact when we weren’t squabbling together we were playing together. 

 I’ve never had a sister and I don’t live in the asoiaf misogynistic society that so openly and structurally calculates ones worth on gender based accomplishments so it’s not quite the same situation. But I do see a lot of my own sibling relationship in Arya and Sansa. One based on mutual immaturity rather than mutual hatred. 

I do think that it would have been more difficult than just suddenly growing out of their antagonistic relationship if The Plot not happened. The world they live in supports Sansa’s view of Arya as an embarrassing wild child and one of them might have still been sent away as a ward or bride before they could work things out. I don’t think they would ever truly see eye to eye but I do think that they could have grown and matured enough to love and support one another. Or to at least be on friendly terms.
trail.content_abstract:
Honestly I read Sansa and Arya’s relationship as more of an average sibling rivalry than anything else. I’ve seen a lot of people claim that the sisters hated each other and made each other miserable but I just don’t see that in the books.

TLDR: Sometimes a sibling rivalry is just a sibling rivalry.

blog.name: thegeekembassy
blog.title: The Geek Embassy
blog.description:
The ambassadors of Geek Embassy endeavor to share all types of geeky passions with our community. As a group, we write individually but we come together to share our collective experiences with different media. For TGE Watches, we talk about movies and TV shows. TGE Plays, we play games together. For TGE Reads, we select a book, read it, and then discuss it together. We are hoping through our collective knowledge and know-how to share these geeky interests with our readers, viewers, and listeners. 

Listen to our podcast at https://www.thegeekembassy.com/category/podcast

summary: How Music has Become a Main Character in Game of Thrones
title: How Music has Become a Main Character in Game of Thrones
body:
How Music has Become a Main Character in Game of Thrones

Game of Thrones is the definition of an ensemble show. Although lots major characters have kicked the bucket in one form or another, there’s still no one main character. But in the past two seasons, another character has come into play. But it’s not the kind of character you might expect.

The music in the show has become instrumental (no pun intended) at conveying emotion. It’s become so…

View On WordPress

summary: I must say I just love how George Martin lets us see what’s going on in Arya’s heart. Not that we need it that much. Arya is a...
body:
I must say I just love how George Martin lets us see what’s going on in Arya’s heart. Not that we need it that much. Arya is a sweet loving person and she’s never shy from showing how she feels. If you hurt someone she loves she will hunt you down and kill you or die trying. If she loves you she will protect you even if it means putting herself in danger or breaking her own heart. But still George gives us these heartbreaking moments when Arya is struggling with her pain, with the love she still feels for the ones that were taken away from her :

“She could feel the hole inside her every morning when she woke. It wasn’t hunger, though sometimes there was that too. It was a hollow place, an emptiness where her heart had been, where her brothers had lived, and her parents.” 

They were her heart and they were stolen from her. After the red wedding, Arya could feel this emptiness inside her for a long time. But she has finally crossed the narrow sea to find Jaqen and we can see there is more to her heart than her family :

“I only came to find Jaqen H'ghar.”

“I do not know this name.”

Her heart sank.

It’s not the first time Arya makes it clear how much Jaqen means to her. She already compared him to Jon Snow in Harrenhal. But here in Braavos, in this dark temple, she’s equating her heart to Jaqen. George Martin can be so romantic sometimes !
